058661.question: can you explain what's this "technological transformation" you are going through in your video making process?
058661.answer: i started using final cut express 4 at almost exactly the same time it was discontinued forever, unbeknownst to me. so as soon as i got good and i had already released hundreds of videos, i suddenly realized that my entire video production process as i know it will have to end at some point, and be completely re-invented, for better or for worse. so i clung to the last surviving computer on earth capable of running the old software, as i continued to gain more and more experience month over month, year over year, on a system that was quickly losing its ability to even run the internet. it's kind of like this: i unexpectedly had the privilege of spending 7 years on level 1. so suddenly i find myself at an experience level 25, still physically on level 1. so now, like some kind of bottle rocket, it is now vividly time to explode straight into level 25, but the psychotic amount of momentum seems to have me headed for at least 4000 or more. there's more levels than i've seen before, must be in the billions

058662.question: I'm thinking of buying a midi keyboard. I've always been interested in music, and I've been making songs on my computer for a few years now, but I'm not very good at it and it's always a struggle. However, I have a feeling that getting a keyboard (I've never played an instrument) could dramatically improve my skills and make everything a lot more fun. But I can't help but feel that this is a foolish thing to hope for. If I'm bad at music now, why would that change if I got a shiny, expensive tool? If I was truly good at it, could I not compose masterpieces with nothing but a pen and paper? And so, I find myself in a dead end of doubt. To elaborate, I imagine that playing a keyboard would let me absorb music theory concepts (namely a feel for harmony) intuitively by playing existing songs (which includes learning them), and noodling around, performing rapid experimentation at a rate 10000 times higher than possible by clicking in notes with a mou se. And playing an instrument seems like something that brings you really close to the music. That's a feeling I long for. I got a taste of it by my DAW that lets me play notes with my computer keyboard, and I had a blast with it (but of course I quickly ran into ghosting and range issues). But on the other hand, I've been dabbling with music for years now (I have over 500 unique projects on my laptop) and still don't have much to show for it. That sounds like a red flag signifying that there is no hope to me. I fear that my keyboard would end up a grand waste of money and space, since I lack the talent needed to operate it. So my question is: is it realistic to hope for a dramatic skill improvement as a result of obtaining a keyboard, or am I a victim of capitalism foolishly hoping that buying something will fix my problems? Sorry that this got so long, but I felt like I needed to write it all down. Thanks for reading this if you did!
058662.answer: keyboards are very friendly. you might be surprised at how friendly they are sure, but if you want it to be music, you're gonna want to get something to play with. music will only be able to survive on the paper if you've already spent seemingly lifetimes with instruments oh man, wow. that's for sure that's true. it's like going to the meat store, always gets you closer to the meat i am pleased to announce that if you get a music keyboard, (as long as you don't get one of the toy ones) it will actually sense how loud/soft you hit the notes. so that will be instantly a whole new layer of feels that you have been completely deprived of, because the computer keyboard is not pressure sensitive that reminds me of a swimmer who has decided how good/bad they are at swimming before actually touching any water it's going to be impossible to learn music without an instrument. even if you only sing, you're probably never gonna feel the power of music until you can play with some chords too. which keyboards tend to enable, quite easily in a friendly manner

058709.question: can i add a wireless keyboard to keyboard maestro as a macro controller? how do i do this so the keyboard won't actually press that key as a main keyboard? i am running out of combinations on my trusty old butterfly keyboard. pls help.
058709.answer: ok, 2 very important things i have to say about this. 1, yes, you can absolutely use additional keyboards with kbm, all with their own separate keys. i'm currently using 9 keyboards. i will explain the trick i discovered for doing that. but the other important thing i must tell you first is that if you start including wireless keyboards in your setup, you will be in agony city. i had 3 wireless keyboards in the setup and it was a disaster. it's occasionally annoying when a bluetooth keyboard disconnects, but if you have 4 bluetooth keyboards it's going to happen 4 times more often. actually more, because bluetooth just gets messed up when you have too many. i returned all the wireless keyboards and went for wired keyboards only. much more reliable. Ok, now that that hint/tip is out of the way, the secret for getting additional keyboards in kbm is first get Karabiner Elements (this is a key-swapping software). But instead of swapping keys, you are actually going to disable every key. (set it to "vk disable".) this may take a while if you go through the popup menus, but if you open the json file you can change it via the text all in one shot (with a little help from kbm of course). Once you have all the keys disabled, go into keyboard maestro and when you make your trigger, instead of "Hot Key" trigger, use "USB device key" trigger, press a button and it will come right up. This works for almost any keyboard you can imagine, even PC keyboards (although you may never get the function key.) Another secret tip that i will tell you is, if extra keyboards don't work when you first try, or if they don't work when you first boot up, just put the computer to sleep then wake it up. quickest way is to go to the lock screen and then unlock (and i've now zapped that with a macro). only have to do it if i restart, otherwise they work forever. it took me a while to figure that out, i thought they mysteriously just didn't work until i went to lunch. email me if you need any more tips, i have learned a lot so far, and it's a strange world, and i've run into a lot of things i didn't expect, but overall it's been much easier than i expected, considering what i've seen Tom Scott and Taran Van Hemert had to go through. and i'm not even sure if peternlewis is even aware that what i'm doing is possible

058718.question: 10.20.19 5:55 pm Thanks for the tips, Bill! I'm currently having some fun writing my song and it may be up on YouTube soon, but I haven't decided the length. Would 7 or 8 seconds work? Or does it need to be 2 seconds? Thanks! -Misha
058718.answer: you can try 7 or 8, but, if you are still feeling overwhelmed, don't forget that you always have the option of actually dialing it back to 1 second. the advantages here are ridiculous. you will finish it very quickly, freeing up time to do 3, 4, 5 second or more. you learn things every time you finish a song, so 1 second means almost instantaneous learning. if you are feeling frozen like you can't do anything and you're confused and can't learn anything, just try something shorter. eventually you will go from learning nothing to learning everything, extremely quickly. and then increase the length from there. it's like going up a staircase. very easy, if you actually start at the bottom

059028.question: how did you do the thing in "hello sexy pants" where there was that one spoken line that only comes out of one side of my headphones? or is my headphone just broken on one side? and why is that line not written in the lyrics on the lyrics page?
059028.answer: that's called 'pan.' it's available in every music making software or hardware ever, as long as you are listening to it in stereo. 'pan' is how far left or right the sound is. actually most music in stereo has all the parts positioned in slightly different places, not just exactly center. occasionally for special effects it is fun to throw something all the way to one side to give the impression that it is outside commentary on the song, instead of actually in the song. also it was not written in the song, it was probably something i came up with when recording the vocal

059216.question: on blender, assuming you are using cycles render, make sure in the render settings in the 'sampling' section the samples value isn't placed too high, because that value is different from the preview value. setting the value too low will add a lot of noise to the image, but setting it too high takes too long
059216.answer: eevee, but i will use whatever you want me to use trying cycles render, that is much slower and/or noisier, (about 13 seconds per frame, and still too much noise, that's at 64 samples) and the viewport is noisy/slow, that would be at 32. Eevee is much faster for both, and with eevee, the preview-viewport version displays absolutely perfectly at 16 samples, absolutely instantly, noise free. And yet, render still takes 1/2 second per frame, at 16 samples. much much better than cycles, but the mystery still persists as to what should stop me from just screenrecording the viewport for perfect instant results ....... and yet the render still needs to compute .... To push this mystery a little bit further, still on eevee, i've set the render sample rate to 1, (!!!) the render still is completely noise free and looks great, (???) and does about 3 frames per second. The viewport preview, however, i've just set to 500 samples (!!!), and it still renders absolutely instantly. ?????? it's got to be aliens

059218.question: Whenever I think about numbers, I find myself getting lost. Like, once you get past 10 nonillion or so, the number you're talking about is so large that there is no meaningful comparison for it in the universe. The largest numbers ever used constructively are Graham's Number and tree(3), both so unbelievably large that the number of digits in the number of digits in the number of digits in them can't be imagined. Yet there are always numbers larger. In fact, considering all the natural numbers in a row, these numbers are functionally no different than 0 in terms of how close to the end you are. Do you ever find yourself getting lost in stuff like this?

059360.question: 11.3.19 1:58 am Wow! That's very encouraging. I know letter chords like C, Am, Fmaj7, Gadd9, etc. And the Nashville number system; like 1 is the root, 2m, 3,4,5 6m, etc. and I understand tempo and keeping time and basic time signature. But as for music sheets with music notes, I can't play by that. I just hear and I play. All that being said, would it benefit me to learn how to read and write music to further expand my knowledge?
059360.answer: well then congratulations, you are fluent, literate, and industry-ready nowadays with recordings so readily available, the importance of completely knowing notation is nothing of what it used to be. there used to be no records, so in order to even listen to music, you had to buy sheet music from the store and play it on the piano. but nowadays, even in a professional setting, if you're learning material, even if you CAN read full notation, it would be actually very irresponsible to not listen to a recording also, because no matter how good the notation is, there's still layers and layers of depth to the music that can never be accurately represented on paper. it depends what kind of work you are doing, but in almost every modern professional musical situation, if you know chord symbols, (and the relative number systems are a huge bonus also), and have good ears to go with it, that's an A grade professional package right there. with the possibly the specific exception of the world of classical orchestral music. Also it may be different if your main instrument is a lead instrument - in that case you might want to know how to read melodies. And in general, i would recommend learning rhythmic notation, because often you will see rhythmic figures written in charts, and also it will be a very valuable tool when talking about the material with other musicians, you can refer to different rhythmic figures. and it would also help to know the names of the notes

059475.question: Bill, you talk about how in order to have absolute pitch, you need some reference point(s) that were instilled from a very young age. But what I do is I compare the note to a pre-selected list of songs, and I can tell the note's pitch by what song it matches. It's not always snap-instant, but I can usually get at least a half-step around the true note. And these songs are ones I have only discovered very recently. So my question: does being able to remember and sing a song in key count as, or at least approximate, absolute pitch?
059475.answer: exactly, that's mostly how i do it. but, .... can you do it while another song is playing to put it to the test you should try to get it to work while another song is playing, and compare it to obtain that song's key. but i will tell you something ironic. you will hear the experts say "no, that doesn't count, that's just sonic memory. the real absolute pitchers can do it instantly." But for me, here's the twist: every single person i've ever met who claims to have absolute pitch, i test them on it and they fail miserably.... by way more than a half step

059642.question: Is your internal "soundtrack-of-your-life" similar to your musical style? Or does your day-to-day life journey have a different vibe/tone? Is your musical style just your "life's work" (object of your journey) or is it closer to being a reflection of your experience in life (representation of your subjective journey)? One possibility I've found myself considering is that your music represents a mix between your efforts to 1. refocus your attention on what will keep your outlook positive and bring you closer to your goals, and 2. recontextualize the internal and external challenges you face in a way that allows you to face them in an arena of your choosing. But I'm doing a hell of a lot of projecting here. Slightly unrelated. I know you don't like listening to your finished music because of superstition-related reasons, but does this keep you from singing and pla ying old songs just for the enjoyment of it? needless to say, if you don't feel like answering the questions themselves but you have some thoughts I'd love to hear em. Thx Bill!
059642.answer: usually it's whatever the last song i heard, that song imprinted in my brain and won't stop until i hear a different song, or think of a different song i just try to write stuff that would blow my mind if i heard it for the first time. whether or not i have ever succeeded in that, is open to debate it's more enjoyable to play new songs, or to play other people's old songs, in a new way. it would also be enjoyable to play my own songs in a new way, but we'll save that for the stage, with the band

059701.question: So I'm working on preparing to work with multiple cover bands and I've found that unless there's Charts, nobody knows what to do because they haven't listened to the recording. which sucks, but that's just all who's available to me where i Live. I just want to know (because I have wet dreams about this) Do the pros REALLY just give the band members a playlist of the setlist and then leave it up to the individual Bandmembers to transcribe and execute their part? because I've been writing EVERYBODYS part down in the group and it's exhausting and time consuming. and in the end the people I'm working with are only up to tackle five tunes a week. and it just feels like: "I have three hours of material(One+half written). At this pace I'm never gonna get to perform live." "how do you climb out of hell?" is my question I guess.
059701.answer: professionals should be able to learn much more than 5 songs a week, especially if they are allowed to read. many people prefer to make their own charts. they should be able to read charts as well, but even if they are good readers, no chart can actually explain exactly how a song is supposed to sound. so even with charts, you have to listen to the song to get the full picture. it's interesting that you can only find readers who won't listen, because i've found it's much more common to find people who listen, try to memorize, and don't even write things down because they can't read

059764.question: 11.8.19 3:47 pm if im willing to put in 5 years to learn 3 or 4 instruments, and the level of good i want to get is about to the level where if i started busking people would hear me and they would say something like "wow youre really really good" and then they give 20 dollars. and that repeats with lots or people that walk by. though i think tou might need some more factors to understand if i should pursue music, such as my singing voice. my singing voice is naturally pretty good (for reference it sounds very similar to your voice, but when singing it sounds different to the point where its unique) my voice is suited for more rock and pop type somgs, but i could also try hip hop type songs, but my voice can not do the growling thing that tends to happen in metal songs. i have a keyboard with 61 keys, (though im poor so its not very good) i hope to learn simple songs, and then everything necassa ry for m y journey to success. i know a bit about basic music theory but i dont know how to put it down and do things, and i dont have the muscle memory to always hit the notes im trying to on triads, because i havent even done any real practice. i cant afford lessons right now. i can picture myself being successful to exactlty the degree i want, but i dont know how to get there, or where to start my journey. i havent been involved with music from a young age. my confidence level is about 60%, but when i get my journey started it will definitely be atleast 90%. based on all these factors would it be a good idea to pursue music? sorry for writing a very long question, i just had so many things i wanted to say. thank you
059764.answer: you can never plan how many instruments you are going to learn. learning an instrument changes your life. once you learn that instrument, it will change everything, including the exact number of instruments you will want to learn after that there is another factor, which is how much you enjoy doing all the things you plan on doing. so first you must calculate how much you are going to enjoy all these things, that way you'll know if you should do them

059969.question: Good to know you're still alive and well, can't wait to see what you'll do with your new software. Gosh so many questions and words to say, hopefully I can express them to you in a reasonable manner lol. I want to be like you, I want to make music and I want to make people happy and entertained like you but I don't know where to start. I just started my life and it feels like I still don't have enough time. I love playing the ukulele, guitar, tenor guitar, and piano (I want to pick up the bass and drums too lmao) but I am really bad at most of them and I don't feel as if I can master them quick enough, and I feel like it'd be too late for me to get lessons on them. As well as I have loads of recording of songs that I have started but I don't know what to do with them, I don't have any type of recording or editing software, and I don't even know what type to get. It feels like I'm just stuck in this hole of, "I want to do it, but I don't have the means t o do it. " And I really want to try to make music for a living. I really hope this hasn't gotten too confusing, but I want to be a successful musician, like you, but I don't know where to start or what to do, and you're one of the only famous people who like actually responds to, pretty much, all of their fans. Do you have any tips on what I should do, or where I should start or anything? P. S. Sorry for making you read this long lol
059969.answer: keep writing songs, recording them, and figure out what's going to play on the screen while the song plays. if you think you can make a video, that's cool too. but if you can't, just designate something interesting to look at on the screen while your song is playing. and make a bunch of video files that have your song on it, with the visual. keep doing that, and make your own channel (even if it's just on your hard drive). keep a notebook, give updates, record commentary, ...... basically make your own tv show. and then after it has gone on for a few months or a year or so, whenver you are feeling ready, start looking around at various online platforms you like best, and make accounts there and start posting the content there. it's pretty much a steady staircase to success, if you start treating yourself like the star of your own show, immediately. i am just guessing at what you might be interested in, because you said "like you" (me), and pretty much what i do is i star in my own imaginary show, and then when i feel like the show is good enough i start posting it online. pretty cool
